description:
The chef that makes the most dishes wins!

Tabula Pasta is a game where the players are all chefs working at a small Italian restaurant. They are trying to out do each other by getting the most satisfied customers. Each customer's order is determined by rolling three special dice (meat, pasta, and sauce). The chefs must race against each other to fulfil the orders using the cards in their hand, the deck, and the pantry. The chef with the most satisfied customers by the end of the game is the winner!

The board game is a table, set for four persons. To begin the game you place a meeple (patron) in each chair. Determine each patron's order by rolling their own set of special dice, one each of a sauce, meat, and pasta die. The players (chefs) then have to match the patron's order by drawing cards from the grocery delivery (deck) or the pantry (three piles of discarded cards, shared by everyone, that haven't been used to fill an order). Once an order has been filled the player shows everyone their match, moves the patron next to them to keep score, places the used cards in the bus bin (discard pile, you can never dig from the trash to complete an order, that's gross!), and finally seats a new patron (if any are left) and rolls a new order for them. Play continues until everyone has been served.

In addition to the six types of pasta, meat, and sauce cards there are also wild cards and secret ingredient cards (a pasta, meat, or sauce that counts as any other type, but you can only use one to fill an order). There are variations for faster games: using less patrons and/or removing the meat cards and dice (light lunch).

It is the year 2056, not much is left of mankind. A nuclear war destroyed all civilisations on earth. The survivors are in desperate need of food. For food, even radiated, means at least short-term survival. Can your group of survivors outlive the other groups in the struggle for food and survival?

Starvation is a quick boardgame that can be played with 2 to 5 players. Although the rules are simple the tactics are not.

The game starts with a board with scattered food tokens. At the start all players take turn placing their survivor pieces on the board. After this the game starts.
Each player first has to choose use up food to let his pieces survive or to give up his pieces. After that he is allowed to let his pieces move, taking with him a limited amount of food. The player with the last survivor on the board wins.

There was an old Lady who swallowed a fly...  This trick-taking game is themed on the popular children’s song. The object is to take tricks by playing the highest-ranked animal card. Problem is, when an animal card is played, its rank changes and usually for the worse.

Before each round, ranking cards are placed on the table in a row in order of rank:  fly, spider, bird, cat, dog, goat, cow, horse. The fly is the lowest ranked at the start, and the horse is the highest. The animal cards are shuffled and dealt. The start player plays a card, and the corresponding card in the rank row is shifted down one space. If an animal is already the lowest ranked animal, it is moved to the furthest space on the right and becomes the highest ranked animal.

Play proceeds clockwise. In turn, each player plays a card. A player must follow suit if possible, otherwise he may play any card.  Each played card causes the corresponding card in the rank row to shift down as described above.

After everyone has played, the player whose card matches the currently highest ranked animal wins the trick (regardless of suit). If two or more players have played the same ‘winning’ card, the player who played first wins the trick.

This is a 3-4 player game. Partnership rules are included as well.

MicroSport Soccer is a fast-playing finger-flicking action game played with a portable board and small coin.

The basic game revolves around players taking turns flicking the coin in an attempt to land it on the goal. Individual player zones govern ball possession, while additional rules cover passing, turnovers, throw-ins, and goal kicks. The adjustable size of each team's player zones and goals allows amateurs to compete with experts.

Your humble tribe has struggled generation after generation for mere subsistence. After eons of hunting and gathering, feasts and famine, war and peace, your people have finally entered an age of innovation.

With the advent of horticulture, your tribe has settled into a sedentary way of life and through this change, idle minds have begun to develop new ways of understanding and manipulating the world around them. Great advancements are being made in subsistence, government, technology, culture, commerce, diplomacy, and warfare.

This sea change has inspired a need for guidance and through careful consideration your people have elected you to lead them into the future.

Civicus is a civilization themed, tile placement and area control game in which players compete for territories, resources and exotic goods. These essential elements of the game are earned, maintained, and developed through sound logic, thoughtful tile placement, and strategic planning.

Each round the players will take turns placing new terrain tiles. Strategic tile placement is crucial for a player’s success, as this aspect of the game determines the geographical matrix for game play and dictates resource and action point generation. Resources and action points are required for nearly every aspect of the game, including settlement and temple construction, attribute development, and wealth generation.

Throughout four ages, the players will compete for territory control, by building and developing settlements. In turn, these territories will provide the players with the raw materials required for cultivating a great and powerful nation. The greatness of your nation is determined, in part, by a preset scoring system which focuses heavily on settlement construction, exotic good control, as well as, fortune and fame.

The nation with the most victory points at the end of the fourth age wins!
          [Crowds cheer… fireworks erupt… enemies conspire]

Demigods Evolution is a skirmish-style board game for 2 or 4 players in which they take the roles of demigods, commanding armies of heroes to prove supremacy over others and ascend as the new God of War. As a demigod, a player initially has access to 24 heroes from which he can choose his army. With his choice he then faces his opponent(s) on sacred battleground.

There are different game modes regarding picking heroes (chieftain, random, mirror, free pick mode), and regarding conditions on which victory is achieved (skirmish, tactics). It is the game that relies heavy on tactics, that is fairly simple to learn but hard to master and that has a great replayability.

In time of Chaos, the God of War was supreme ruler over all other gods. But Time of Peace came, and lasted so long that God of War started to lose his power. He grew weaker as the years went by and was pushed to the side by other gods. When his power faded so much that he felt that the end was near he gave the task to his four sons, the demigods, to try to prove themselves as best commanders in the field of battle. The one who can emerge victorious should become the new God of War and bring back the former glory to their name.

Gather your heroes, challenge your friends, become the God of War!

In this game Snoopy has four different wishes: becoming a top pilot, top baseball player, top dog or famous writer. (Each of the cards is 4 times in the game.) All players (2-8) try to collect the five cards that are part of the same wish.

You can collect by walking around on the board or owing to a 'menu-card'. The first player who collects his 5 cards is the winner.

Playout: The Game™ makes fitness fun for people of all ages and fitness abilities. Turn bodyweight exercise into a fun competition with over 10 unique games and infinite exercise combinations, all using a single deck of cards. Why workout when you can PLAYOUT!


     Play alone or with friends
     No additional equipment needed!
     Full body fitness in 10 minutes of fun!


Playout: The Game™ is an exercise card game that makes fitness fun through social play, competition, variety, and adaptability. With Playout, you can get fit while having fun, anywhere, anytime.

30 BODYWEIGHT EXERCISE CARDS - 10 Upper, 10 Core, 10 Lower - A comprehensive full body calisthenic routine for all fitness levels. Each card features an individual exercise and includes direction and tips on how to perform the excercise.  In addition, each card includes three rep counts to vary the difficulty as well as a point value for completing the reps for the exercise.

12 WILDCARDS - Challenges to increase the difficulty and variability of the exercises by adding reps, incorporating new motions or body positions, slowing down motions, or adding new exercises.  Depending on the game played, the Wild (i.e. Joker) cards include directions for each of the difficulty levels that can be applied to an Exercise card to make it more difficult. Additional points are awarded for completing the Joker cards.


     8 MINIGAMES - Intensely fun competitions that push you to the limit. When these cards are encountered, a mini game occurs that really ratchets up the game.  10 or 20 additional points can be earned for both participating and winning the minigame.


Stretch, Warm-Up, Cool-Down, Rule, and Information Cards

GAMES

     The Playout deck can either used as an activity to facilitate an exercise routine, or it can be used to play several games.  These games can be played as individual players or team vs. team:
         Playout Pro (High Intensity)
         The 6 Minute Playout (Moderate/High Intensity)
         Playout Rummy (Low/Moderate Intensity) - Be the first to get rid of all you cards by making sets.  From each set made, choose an exercise for yourself and opponents to perform.  Award points to those who complete the exercises.
         Playout Grand Prix 
         Playout All-Star
    


SCORING

     In general, scoring works as follows:
         Exercise Card:
             Full reps - 10 points + WildCard value
             At least half the rep = WildCard value
             Less then half the reps = no points
        
         MiniGame Card:
             Qualify = 10 points
             Winner = 20 points
        
    


The player (or team, if playing in teams) with the most points  at the end of a particular game (or set of games in the case of a multi-game competition) is the winner.

Game appeared in the Postman Pat Annual for 1995.

Children are encouraged to take a walk through Greendale village and meet some of their favourite characters.

Simple roll and move game for pre-school children. Players must obey instructions if they land on a pink space. The first to reach space Z, wins.

Game featured in the Postman Pat Annual for 1994.

Simple game for pre-school children.

Each player uses one of the two pictures. The pictures are divided in to 10 oblong segments. These are numbered from one to four. In a turn, the player rolls the die and if he rolls a 1, 2, 3, or 4, he covers one segment with that number (use a piece of card or similar to mark that the segment has been rolled). If a 5 is rolled on the die, the player must uncover one of the segments. If a 6 is rolled, the player can cover two segments of his choice.

First player to cover all 10 segments, wins.

Game appeared in the Postman Pat Annual for 1993.

A simple roll and move game for pre-school children.

Players must get from Sam Waldron's house to Pat's house for tea. Move according to your die roll and obey any light brown spaces you land on. First to get to the end of the route, wins.

Game appeared in the Postman Pat Annual for 1993.

Two players are required. Each gets a picture board featuring 6 characters from the Postman Pat stories. In your turn, roll a die. Using playing cards as 'markers', you cover the picture that matches your roll on the die. If you roll the same number twice, you miss a turn. First to cover all six characters on their picture board, wins.
Mickey Mouse Flip Chip is an odd kind of connect 4 game, you use levers built into the base to launch chips up that randomly fall into the board. First player to 4 in a row wins.

Collect a Corpse is a tile laying, build your own royal corpse, game for two players. There is also some dice rolling.

You start the game with either the torso of the king or the queen of Sweden. The goal is to finish your corpse as complete  as possible with your own limbs at the right places.

On your turn you draw a card that either shows a bodypart of either the king or the queen, a black dice or a white dice.
If it's a bodypart (it doesn't have to be your own) place it on your torso. You can later exchange them for parts matching your torso if you have the maximum number of that part (usually 2).
If it's a card roll a die and see the charts: The white die is usually constructive for you and the black die destructive for your opponent.

When the last card is drawn you score points. Parts matching your torso score double points if they are in the right place otherwise the score the number printed on them (inner parts give 2 the outer 3 points). You get no points for the opponents parts on your body.

Democracy was published in the year of the first democratic elections in South Africa - 1994.

In Democracy you are the leader of a political party. All players try to increase their influence with partymembers and their assets such as business, news papers, TV etc. (75 influence cards). Some of the character- and asset-cards show guaranteed votes. The assets must be assigned to a character.
Players can trade their influence cards (assets) freely.

There are 120 event cards with positive and negative effects - so there is a lot of luck. These generate income, which is needed to pay some bad events or the travel-costs from region to region by car or plane, or have direct effects to your political reputation.

The partymembers travel throughout the country canvassing in the regions. Each region has a base resistance of 7. The influence of the canvassing partymember(s) + their assets + D6 must be greater to win the region. Players mark their regions with vote counters - each region is worth 1 vote.

An election is called - 2 ways:
- Automatically after all 50 regions are won, or
- A player can call for an election if he has one of 3 election-card (and only after a minimum of rounds are over, depending on number of players).
Than the last 5 rounds are played. In this "window period" nearly everything is allowed. Players can play special influence cards such as muckrakers, callgirls, third forces or assassins to "destroy" the political reputation or even kill the party leader. Hopefully he has (and can pay) bodyguards ...
Only in this period a player can take a region from another party.

Winning of the game - 2 ways:
- When all other party leaders are killed you win
- After the election, the player with the most votes wins.

A diceless card driven Euro style board game about a Zombie Pandemic on the US Passenger Rail Network.

Description from the Kickstarter:

"In Zomtrack, the cards control the action.

You draw a hand of cards and use them to implement the strategy you have chosen. Back the survivors and spend your time destroying infestations and gaining victory points (VPs) and bonus cards. Did the horde you backed become dominant? Did the survivors’ strongholds hold out? End-of-game bonus cards score based on how well the strategy you backed ends up working."

La Patrie en Danger is another fine game from OSG's publisher Kevin Zucker's famous series "The Library of Napoleonic Battles". Based on the epic "Napoleon's Last Battles"-System, (further upgraded to the Library of Napoleonic Battles): it shows 480 meters per hex, 1 hour per turn, 400-800 men per strength point. Each Approach to Battle game lasts about 20 turns. The Full campaign links the individual battles.

This game contains five battles from the opening phase of the 1814 Campaign in France following the Battle of Nations, which was fought just half a year before at Leipzig.

Napoleon has just arrived at the front. At their first encounter the French surprised Blücher's Prussians and Russians during a snowstorm. The Battle of Brienne was a short-lived success, however, for just two days later the Prussians triumphed at La Rothière and wrote-off the enemy as a spent force, advancing hell-for-leather across the Marne and onto the highway to Paris. Ten days later Napoleon seized his opportunity when "Marschal Vorwärts" allowed his advancing columns to get dispersed and defeated in detail, in rapid succession in three short sharp combats.

BATTLES SIMULATED 
Brienne Unskilled Fury, 29-30 January. 
The raw conscripts under Napoleon and Ney chased the Russians and Prussians from the town. Bluucher himself was almost captured.

La Rothière A Defeat on French Soil, 1 February. 
Reinforced with troops from the Army of Bohemia, Blücher was ready to fight again. Napoleon, not realizing the enemy's overwhelming superiority, advanced. At Noon Blücher attacked, taking 54 guns and inflicting 6,000 French casualties.

Champaubert, 10 February. 
Marmont ran into an isolated corps of 4,500 Russians commanded by Olsufief. Marmont attacked and dispersed the Russian corps, capturing its commander.

Montmirail, 11 February. 
Mortier pinned down Yorck and Kleist's Prussians to the front, while Napoleon separated Sacken's Russians from their allies, sending them streaming back towards Château Thierry.

Vauchamps, 14 February. 
Marmont held Blücher's Prussians in check while Napoleon made a flank march through the mud, sending Grouchy's cavalry round to the rear to cut their retreat to Châlons.

COMPONENTS
Three 22" x 34" maps
560 counters
100 cards
2 rulebooks
15 player aids
Box

GAME SYSTEM: 
The Library of Napoleonic Battles - formerly known as the "Napoleon's Last Battles (NLB-)Series" 
- scale = 480m/hex, 
- time = 1hour/GT,
- strength = 500-800 men/SP.

DDR Forest is a two-player constructible board game that combines strategy and luck. Collect three Relic Cards and land on your opponent’s Starting Square. Die rolls determine your movement. Cards are played to hinder your opponent’s progress. The board unfolds at random each turn allowing for a different map every game.

There are three main actions that the player can decide to play:
Play a valid combination of cards on the table.
Add one or more cards to an existing combination of cards.
Draw a card from the deck if you don't play any cards.

The defining feature of Machiavelli is being able to make changes to the combinations of cards already on the table. The current player, if desired, may reorganize the cards in order to make new combos that make it easier to play one or more cards in his hand. All new combinations must be valid, and players can not remove any cards already on the table.

The player who manages to play all the cards in his hand wins the game.

There is a fundamental difference from Rummy/Manipulation: there is no discarding, which makes it far more difficult to get rid of all cards.

Players place triangular tiles with colored edges, trying to form squares. However, tiles can only be placed in a way so that adjacent edges have the same color. Some triangles contain apples or pears. Forming squares where all tiles contain the same fruit yields double points.

Pochecko is a strategy board game that combines aspects of Poker and Chess. It is a 2-4 player game for ages 12+.

In Pochecko, the players move markers around a board in order to claim poker cards and build a poker hand off of 1 of 2 community cards.  As a counter maneuver, players may instead move one of the community blockers in order to block opponents from claiming the hand they are going for. The player with the best 5 card poker hand at the end of the game wins.

Das Rethorische Quartett is a trick taking and communication game.

First, player agree on a topic and on opineons every player represents.
Each player has cards in his hand showing a kind of argumentations (not an argument, but something lika "non-representative statistic" or "personal attack" or "interpretational sovereignty". By turns players play cards and word an argument according to the card and the actual topic.

The cards have a letter and number and you can only play cards higher then the card played before.

As soon as no one can play an additional card, the one how played the last card gets the stack and the game continues with a new topic.

The player who scores the most cards is the winner.

FROM THE BOX:
Based on the hit tv game show.

The fast-action quiz game developed just for kids! Featuring over 2000 fun and challenging questions.

Jeopardy!'s trademark is that answers must be asked in the form of a question.
Introductory level set of rules designed with 15mm miniatures representing troops of the various armies of the Napoleonic Wars c. 1800-1815

Rulebook for miniature wargaming in the Napoleonic period from about 1792 up to 1815. The particular focus is on simulating the conflict of British and French armies in Spain and Portugal between 1807 and 1814.

The book comes with a complete set of wargame rules and campaign rules, including various options and a large campaign map.

A game intended to teach music score reading skills and music scales. In a game similar to Parcheesi/Ludo, three pawns have to move around a board comprised of chromatical scales, only using the notes belonging to one specific musical key.

The town's pizza bakers are well known for their delicious pizzas. To make sure they are freshly prepared, each pizza baker has installed a pizza oven in his delivery van. The customer receives the freshest pizza, baked hot and crispy right outside his front door.

The players are all pizza bakers with their own pizza oven express vans. The game board is a town "map" with roads, signal lights, barriers, one-way streets, supermarkets and six pizza customers.

Todays pizza customer is decided by throwing the die. A cute littel wodden house is placed on the location to identify where to deliver the pizza.
All the bakers then set off in their vans to deliver the pizza to the hungry customer. If you are the first to arrive at the customer's house, you will recieve moey for your pizza before a new customer shows up. To win the game you must be the fastes pizza baker three times.

It is a turn based game where you have two options each turn after having trown the dice: Drive in the direction of the pizza customer, or play a card.

The cards give the following possible actions: 
- Switch trafic light from red to green or green to red.
- Open or close a barrier.
- Blocking a street in both directions
- Turning a steet into a one-way street.
- Move your opponent's van by the number thrown - usually in reverse.
- Request all players to visit a supermarket to stock up supplies before continuing to the customer.
- Cancel pizza order and throw the dice to decide who is the new pizza customer.

The number of cards are limited for each delivery round (3-5 depending of number of players), and not restocked untill a pizza is delivered.

A fast game about delicious pizzas and fast pizza bakers!

All parts made of wood.

Pip•Pip is a strategic board game of conversion and compromise. It is inspired in equal parts by Sudoku and Triple Triad.

There are two players, both with a handful of six-sided dice.

On each player's turn, he rolls a die and place it on a space within a 4×4 grid.

When players place a die in a space horizontally or vertically adjacent to an opponent’s die, they check the numbers on the two dice that are facing each other. If the number on the current player's die is greater, the opponent’s die is converted to the current player's color.

Players continue placing dice and converting die colors until all the spaces in the 4×4 area are filled. Once this occurs, the game is over and the players tally their scores.

The game usually comes down to the wire, with the winner achieving victory by the skin of his teeth.
Presents information on the organization of the respective armies during the war, the Orders of Battle for several actions as well as some information on flags and standards of the period

The Deer Stalking Game.

The board shows a deer park divided into two Chases by a high wall which has gaps through it. If a huntsman moves on to the same straight line as the stag (providing there is no obstruction of wall or rock in between) the stag is counted as dead and is removed from the board. There are five stags to bag and the winner is the huntsman who bags the largest number of stags.

The huntsmen throw the dice in turn and move along the brown dots according to the number cast. They can only move from dot to dot along the straight lines. They cannot turn corners and they must move the exact number or not at all. If a huntsman moves on to the same straight line as the stag (providing there is no obstruction of a wall or rock in between) the stag is counted as dead and becomes their trophy.

The part of the stag is played by the two huntsmen in turn as follows: a huntsman moves his own piece first then if he wishes he can move the stag either one or two dots in a straight line.

Although the game is undated, Robert Ross & Co were based in Southampton from 1945 to 1952.
Typical spin and move board game. Object of the game is to reach the fire and return to the starting point.

"First, there was law and apparent order. But law's reach was limited. In those untouched corners, there was chaos. Chaos can be exploited, can give unimaginable rewards for those with enough courage and ability. Now rival families struggle for supremacy on the streets. I advice you to step aside, or you could find yourself in a shallow grave. You know, family matters belongs to family..."

The Orcfather is a card game based on a fantasy-themed mafia in which a player's characters can be orcs, elves, ogres, undead, dwarves and more. The players form two mafia families that are confronting one another, and each of the families elects its own "godfather" at the start of the game; the goal of the game is to eliminate the head of the rival family.

Each round starts with a planning phase in which players must secretly prepare the actions they plan to take — attack, defend, or business — but players cannot speak to one another during this phase. They must use their intuition to develop plans as a team, predicting the actions of both allies and enemies. Once all players have decided, they act in order.

While the attack and defend actions are somewhat obvious, for the business action players draw from the business deck, gaining cards that enhance their attacks, potentially save allies from complicated situations, and more.

This is educational roll and move game about Helsinki city district of Töölö. Players are rolling the dice and moving across the streets of Helsinki. There are 24 places of interest and if players happen to stumble on them, then they must answer some questions. If the player knows the right answer, he/she might get some kind of reward (extra throw of dice, get further). If the player's answer is not correct, he/she might get punished (miss a turn, go backwards). First one to finish is the winner.

A game from Wilkinson's self-published 'Mr.' range.  The aim of One Minute Challenge is to complete five one-minute long challenges, for example naming forms of transport or types of curry, or memorising a shopping list.  The game comes with a deck of cards each containing a challenge and a sand timer.  A player who successfully completes a challenge keeps the challenge card, and the first player to reach the target number of cards wins.

The Beer Nerd™ game is a beer tasting game from the creators of the Winerd® game. Taste 3 beers at the start then answer trivia questions and take blind tastes to advance. Think you know your beers? Then Put Your Beer Where Your Mouth Is!
Roll and move game with a travel theme published in France (1880 - 1900). Players visit exotic locations and world Capitals. Starting and ending in France.

Crypt Crashers:
  Cooperative Board Game
  1-5 players
  45 minute play time

Crypt Crashers is a highly thematic cooperative board game. Players take turns exploring the crypt and collect clues. If they select the right clues, they will reveal the location of hidden treasure. As the game progresses, mummies and giant spiders begin to awaken. The players must work together and be quick. Time is running out.

Crypt Crashers has nine levels of difficulty and 8 different expeditions to keep the players challenged.

The objective of this game is to hunt down and destroy the monsters and collect gear. Each opponent and gear has a point cost that is added at the end of the game to determine the winner. Objectives can shift during the game depending on the game scenario you are playing and your character’s Dark Secret motivation.

Minigame complete with full rules, game tiles and game cards. This is a layered PDF giving you four options of colours and a horde of zombies. There are 94 possible miniatures in this set!

You will need a colour printer, cutting tools, glue, foamcore and time. Assembly instructions are included.

Nominated for the 2012 Ennies Best Miniature Product Award

It's the roaring '20s and there's a fortune to be made steaming across the wild oceans. To succeed, you'll need a captain's steady nerve and the help of Lady Luck to land your cargo where it's needed. You have ships full of passengers and precious cargo, but can you outrun pirate robbers, terrifying storms and a stock market crash that might devalue your goods?

Manifest is a game of cargo ships, sea scoundrels, and nautical mayhem. Win points for your shipping company by completing Contracts. Pick up the required goods or passengers at their source, then navigate the high seas to deliver them to their destination. With a choice of private and public contracts and multi-purpose action cards, there are many paths to victory, and some "take that" options to make sure your opponents don't steal the limelight.

Manifest can be played in two ways: Standard and Expert. The Standard game is the introductory and family game. The Expert game builds on this, with a deck-buying and building mechanism replacing the blind card draw, thus adding another level of strategy that confident players may prefer.

Objective: be the first ending on space 89
- moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game - roll the die, move forward & follow instructions printed on lid inside if you end on a marked space.

Remarks:
Belongs to series: "Scholz' künstlerische Spiele";
Likely published ~1920s
Movers: pewter figures

Funny or Die consists double sided cards featuring a funny picture on one side and a caption on the other. Each player has a hand of these cards with the remainder making up the deck. An active player rolls a die which determines both the money wagered on the round and if the round will use pictures, captions, or the player's choice. A card is drawn from the deck for each player, who must then pair it with an opposite card from their hand.

In the voting round, each player has a funny token and a die token with identical backs. Players place a funny token on the funniest pair and a die token on the least funny (players may not vote for themselves). A tie leads to a run-off vote. The tokens are flipped up and the player with the most funny tokens takes the money wagered. The next player then rolls the die for a new round.

When a player loses all their money, the game ends. The player with the most money wins the game.

Íslandssöguspilið is at it's base a roll & move game, with some cards that help you affect other players, by slowing them down or moving their pawns back.

From the back of the box:
An exciting race through Icelandic history. Take part in a race through Icelandic history from the Age of Settlement to the current era. Learn about the persons and events that have shaped the country and it's people.

Pick up two of the face-down tin cans, shake each one. If the sounds are identical, you have a matching pair, keep it, and search for the next pair.
The 12 pairs of tin cans have transparent covers, each pair contains different seeds of different size, weight (and color, though the latter does not play a big role here – one could use it also as a standard memory game for hearing-impaired people, of course). Some similar sized seeds produce VERY similar sounds, so the game is not at all easy.
The game box also contains a booklet explaining the different seeds in detail (it unfortunately does not explain the game rules, but then any one familiar with Memory games will not need any explanation).
"Horch" is kind of an old-fashioned German word for "Listen!".

The players have to move 1 meeple (diver) from the starting space to space 90. The red spaces have special meanings, which are explained in the game rules. Also explained are several facts about diving and oceanic life. The winner is the player who gets the most playing chips on the red spaces.

The game was inspired by the 1956 documentary movie "Le Monde du silence" by Jacques-Yves Cousteau and the invention of the aqualung.

How well do you actually remember the eighties? A time when phasmatidaes were a pet and when the popsicle stick was sometimes a piece of chewing gum. A time when we played UNO, ate kassler with pineapple and knew exactly what we were going to answer to the question "What about couples!?" but not on the question "Are you PK?".

Helballa 80-talet is an entertaining quiz with 318 questions about typical thing from the 80s.

Based on the hit ITV game show from 1993-2001 & 2007 with Dale Winton as your host, answer questions correctly and go wild in the aisles as you race to get the most items in your trolleys as possible in order to win.

From July to October 1942, in the area between the Don and Volga Rivers, the German army broke through the Soviet defense and rushed to Stalingrad. They aimed to occupy the important city facilities (such as Mamai Hill, tractor factory and grain silos). However, Soviet reinforcements poured in and fought back.

Urban warfare is expanded on the Stalingrad city mini-map.

Scale
Counters: division, corps
Hex: about 10 km (normal map) / about 2.4 km (Stalingrad city map)
Turn: 4 days

120 counters

Get Wasted is english version of the czech most popular beer drinking game Chlastej!

Goal of the game:
You are sitting with your friends in a beautiful pub and think what the hell are we going to do? One of you challenges
everybody to a Competition the first who gets lucky at the whore house wins! Everyone is in so the point of this game is clear –
get from the pub to the whore house first and give the best performance ever. Unfortunately after those few beers the way isnt as easy as it might seem and first you need is a pass from your local pimp. This pass is also confirmation that you have enough money to pay and you can still give a solid performance. You are always leaving the pub with a full pint of beer. On your way through the fields you drink gradually from your pint.

Players rolls the dice and move on the game plan. When the game say player have to drink (usually beer).
First player in the whore house is the winner of the game.

English version Get Wasted is only translation of the popular czech game Chlastej!

FROM THE BOX:

Haven't you always wondered who your perfect match is? The New Perfect Match Game is the fun way to find out. The game is played by couples who are asked a series of questions with four alternative answers supplied. These questions cover topics ranging from sex to politics and the arts. Each partner decides on their favourite response and uses the electronic Perfect Match device to check their compatibility and advance along the board. the first couple to reach the Perfect Match Heart Light are the winners. Who will be your Perfect Match?

Contents:

2 Electronic Perfect Match Devices.
288 Question Cards.
1 Die.
4 Position Markers.
Perfect Match Game Board.

The players are divided into couples. Each couple takes a position marker and places it in the start square. Remove the perfect match cards from their perforations and place them in their marked positions on the game board.

The Perfect Match Cards:
These cards are divided into two categories: pink 'Girls' cards and blue 'Guys' cards. As the game proceeds, question cards are taken from the 'Girls' pile if the playing couple lands on a pink square or From the 'Guys' pile if they land on a blue square. Each card contains one questions with four alternative
answers marked A,B,C or D.

Choosing the right answer:
If the couple lands on a blue square, one of the other players picks up a 'Guys' card and directs one question on it to the male partner. He must choose the alternative which he feels is most appropriate to him. His partner must try to anticipate his feelings or attitudes on that question and choose the same alternative. Couples should be open and honest in their choice of answer. Similarly, if the couple lands on a pink square, a 'Girls' card would be taken and its question directed towards the female partner. She will choose and answer and her partner should try to anticipate this response.

Questions marked 'BOTH' are  designed to test compatibility, with each partner choosing their own favourite answer in response to the question asked.

Using the Electronic Perfect Match device:
These devices are in the shape of four hearts joined together. Each heart is labeled A,B,C or D, representing the four alternatives on the Perfect Match question cards. When a question is asked and each partner has silently decided on which alternative to choose, they each hold up their device with the chosen representative letter uppermost. They must not allow each other to see their choices. The two devices are then pressed together. If the electronic tone sounds, a perfect match has been achieved for that question.

Dare Cards:
Scattered throughout both packs of cards are Dare Cards. If one these cards appears, the couple must perform whatever is required of them according to the instructions on the card. Their performance is adequate (as indicated by a show of hands) then the couple may roll the die again and continue their turn. Be warned - if you are too easy on others then there is no challenge to perform well. If you are too tough, then your opponent will be equally tough on you. So be fair!

Playing the game: Each couple rolls the die once and those with the highest score start, moving their marker the corresponding number of squares. One of the other players then reads the first question to the starting couple. If the couple achieves a Perfect Match, they roll the die again and advance the corresponding number of squares along the board. Remember, a couple can only roll the die and advance after  they have successfully answered a Perfect Match question or performed a Dare task. The couple continues in this way until they are unsuccessful in either a Perfect Match question or a Dare performance, in which case the control of the game is handed over to the next couple (moving clockwise).

Winning the Game:
The first couple to reach the Perfect Match Heart Light and then successfully achieve a Perfect Match from their Choice of either a Girls or Guys question will be declared the winner.


    Special Note


Should the electronic tone stop working use a nail file or a similar tool to lever apart the two case sections of the blue device. Carefully removed the battery, replacing it with one of identical type. Be sure to position it positive side up. When pressing the case sections back together, locate the letter "A" on the plastic cover over the battery position.

Based on the formerly popular 1980s Network Ten (and much later Seven Network in 2002) Australian TV dating game show of the same name.

A game for 2 players by Stefano Negro.

In the Glorious Republic of Chetyrestan, Comrades are being assigned different accommodations to live in. Players are government planners giving a place to stay to everyone while trying to create a peaceful and functional city.

Components

6 City Stripes (6×1 squares). Each square is in one of the three Building colors (white, black, or green).

36 Buildings divided into:


     12 Class A Flat
     12 Class B Flat
     12 Class C Flat


36 Comrades divided into:


     12 Diplomats
     12 Bureaucrats
     12 Workers


8 District Tokens (2×A, 2×B, 2×C, 2×D)

1 Supervisor Token

Aim of the game

The players place/move Buildings and Comrades trying to get 4 Buildings or 4 Comrades of the same colour in an orthogonal or diagonal row multiple times to create a functional district in Chetyrograd (in order to get rewards).
